item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:19, topic:160826”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=218858.msg1916012#msg1916012 date=1196921259]

Slashshot007, can you kindly explain what those parameters are, other than color?

sure, actually its goes:
color, TOP-RIGHT X Coordinate, TOP-RIGHT Y Coordinate, BOTTOM-LEFT X Coordinate, BOTTOM-LEFT Y coordinate.
i thought that should have been a given. should I change it so you only need to top x and y coordinates, and then get the length and width?

An even better solution would be to use an instance of java.awt.Rectangle.
[/quote]
and waste memory on a needless constructor, whats the point, 4 ints are fine[/quote]

Rectangle already needs to be instantiated using the parameters for the screen shot. It would actually save the memory used to duplicate the four ints when calling the method.

Read full topic

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @Slashshot007 Slashshot007
item.description:
@Slashshot007 wrote:

i realized that there can be a billion ways to do this lol. heres another basic way i figured out how to do it.

[code] private static Point findColor(Color color, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2){
try {
Robot robot = new Robot();
BufferedImage image = robot.createScreenCapture(new Rectangle(x1-1,y1-1,Math.abs(x1-x2)+1,Math.abs(y1-y2)+1));
int colorint = color.getRGB();
for(int y = 0; y < y2-y1; y++)
for(int x = 0; x < x2-x1 ; x++)
if(image.getRGB(x,y)==colorint){
return new Point(x+x1,y+y1);
}

	}catch(java.awt.AWTException exc) {
		return new Point(-1,-1);
	}
	return new Point(-1,-1);
}[/code]

it returns -1,-1 if it cannot find the point

Read full topic

item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

@Taharok: It appears that there is something wrong with isEqual. It will start searching and if the first pixel is the one colour you want then it will return it. Otherwise it will never break and point will be null.

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:9, topic:160826”]Here is something I just whipped up, try it out:

public static Point findColor(Color clr, int prgrmX, int prgrmY, BufferedImage src) {
	boolean isEqual = true;
	Point point = null;
	ColorModel model = new DirectColorModel(24, 0xff0000, 0x00ff00, 0x0000ff, 0x0);
	int color = model.getRGB(model.createCompatibleWritableRaster(1, 1).getElements(0, 0, null));
	for (int h=0; h<src.getHeight(); h++)
		for (int w=0; w<src.getWidth(); w++) {
			isEqual = color == src.getRGB(h, w) && isEqual;
			if (isEqual) {
				point = new Point(h, w);
				break;
			}
		}
	return point;
}

That will compare a single pixel of the desired color with all the pixels of the image until it finds one of its own color. It will then return the location of that single pixel it found. If it cannot find any pixels of that color, it will return null.

Also, you should declare the ColorModel as a field so that it does not have to be repeatedly re instantiated.[/quote]

Aye, and for improved efficiency have only 1 for loop, and yes it is possible.

Read full topic

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Here is something I just whipped up, try it out:

public static Point findColor(Color clr, int prgrmX, int prgrmY, BufferedImage src) {
	boolean isEqual = true;
	Point point = null;
	ColorModel model = new DirectColorModel(24, 0xff0000, 0x00ff00, 0x0000ff, 0x0);
	int color = model.getRGB(model.createCompatibleWritableRaster(1, 1).getElements(0, 0, null));
	for (int h=0; h<src.getHeight(); h++)
		for (int w=0; w<src.getWidth(); w++) {
			isEqual = color == src.getRGB(h, w) && isEqual;
			if (isEqual) {
				point = new Point(h, w);
				break;
			}
		}
	return point;
}

That will compare a single pixel of the desired color with all the pixels of the image until it finds one of its own color. It will then return the location of that single pixel it found. If it cannot find any pixels of that color, it will return null.

Also, you should declare the ColorModel as a field so that it does not have to be repeatedly re instantiated.

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“Slashshot007, post:7, topic:160826”]heres how i did it:private static Point findColor(Color color, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2){ try { Robot robot = new Robot(); for(int x = x1; x<x2; x++){ for(int y = y1; y<y2;y++){ if(robot.getPixelColor(x,y).equals(color)) return new Point(x,y); } } }catch(java.awt.AWTException exc) { return new Point(-1,-1); } return new Point(-1,-1); }
but I’ve recently been told that using getPixelColor every time may slow down the speed dramatically?
If so, i’ll change it so i you take a screenshot of the screen.[/quote]
Yes incredibly, you need to copy the image then buffer it and get the wraster to grab the pixel array and then search, it’s alot quicker… Like TONS.

Read full topic

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @r4ndom1 r4ndom1
item.description:
@r4ndom1 wrote:

heres an old way I used to implement it into rs which is probably a faster but it does not work with minimization:

package colourmethods;
 
import java.awt.Component;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;
import java.awt.GraphicsConfiguration;
import java.awt.GraphicsDevice;
import java.awt.GraphicsEnvironment;
import java.awt.Transparency;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
 
public class AppletImage implements Runnable 
{
	private BufferedImage img;
	private Component RS;
	private Thread t;
	private int RGB;
	private RGB[][] pixels;
	private Graphics2D g;
 
	public void run()
	{
		while(true)
		{
			RS.paint(g);
			for(int y = 0;y >= RS.getHeight();y++)
			{
				for(int x = 0; x >= RS.getWidth();x++)
				{
					pixels[x][y] = new RGB(img.getRGB(x, y));
				}
			}
 
			try
			{
				t.sleep(1000/20);
			}
			catch(InterruptedException e)
			{
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
		}
 
	}
 
	public AppletImage(Component rs)
	{
		GraphicsEnvironment ge = GraphicsEnvironment.getLocalGraphicsEnvironment();
		GraphicsDevice gd = ge.getDefaultScreenDevice();
		GraphicsConfiguration gc = gd.getDefaultConfiguration();
 
		img = gc.createCompatibleImage(rs.getWidth(), rs.getHeight(), Transparency.BITMASK);
 
		g = img.createGraphics();
 
		RS = rs;
 
		t = new Thread(this);
		t.start();
	}
}

Read full topic

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Google’s Answer:

public Point FindColor(Color c,int x1,int y1,int x2,int y2,int tol){ BufferedImage image= createScreenCapture(new Rectangle(x1-1,y1-1,Math.abs(x1-x2)+1,Math.abs(y1-y2)+1)); double tolLevel=tol/100.0; int rgb=c.getRGB(); for (int i=y1;i<=y2;i++){ for(int j=x1;j<=x2;j++){ int c1=image.getRGB(j, i); if (Math.abs(rgb-c1)/16777215.0<=tolLevel){ return new Point(j,i); } } } return null; }

Read full topic

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Another way to do it:

[code]public static final Point getPointByColor(Color color, int x, int y, int width, int height) throws Exception {
Robot robot = new Robot();

 for(int i = y; i < height; i++)
      for(int j = x; j < width; j++)
           if(robot.getPixelColor(j, i).getRed() == color.getRed() && robot.getPixelColor(j, i).getGreen() == color.getGreen() && robot.getPixelColor(j, i).getBlue() == color.getBlue())
                return new Point(j, i);
 
 return null;

}[/code]

You would need to import the following:

import java.awt.Color; import java.awt.Point; import java.awt.Robot;

item.title: Findcolor Method - Source
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

This is a simple fincolor method I use in Jmacro. It’s very fast, searches the whole screen in a few ms without using much memory. I’m releasing this because I’m ditching this method and working on a much more advanced one.

It works like:

findcolor(Red,Green,Blue,Red Tolerance,Green Tolerance,Blue Tolerance,Case found on screen);

Default for tolerance must be 1 and case must be 0…

So here it is…please leave credits if you use this (doubt most of you leechers will but whatever)…

package com.vibesoft.bots;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.*;
import java.lang.Object;
import java.awt.Robot; 
import java.awt.image.*;

public class findcolor{
public static boolean findcolor(int realred,int realgreen,int realblue, int redtol, int greentol, int bluetol, int times)
{
boolean found = false;
int loop = 0;
try
        {
        Robot r = new Robot();
        Dimension size = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenSize();
        BufferedImage img = r.createScreenCapture(new Rectangle(size));
		for (int y = 0; y < size.height; y++)
        {
            for (int x = 0; x < size.width; x++)
            {
                Color c = new Color(img.getRGB(x,y));
				int red = c.getRed();
				int green = c.getGreen();
				int blue = c.getBlue();
				if (realred > red - redtol & realred < red + redtol & realgreen > green - greentol & realgreen < green + greentol & realblue > blue - bluetol & realblue < blue + bluetol) {
				r.mouseMove(x,y);
				loop = loop + 1;
				found = true;
				if (loop > times) {
				return found;
				}
				}
            }
        }
        }
        catch (AWTException e)
        {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
		return found;}
		}
//Call this method with findcolor(R,G,B,R tolerance + or -,B tolerance,G tolerance,times to move); and it will move your mouse when it finds the pixel; 0 for "times" means the first case

Enjoy.

Read full topic
